III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12206
Section (1) An agency shall require a staff member who has ongoing
Description contact with children or parents to be a person who has the ability,
experience, education, and training to perform the duties
assigned.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
1

Allegation Staff use derogatory language with youth and threaten to kick
youth out of placement or intimidate youth if they call CPS. Staff
have been racist against African American youth.
Investigation On 3/24/22 DCWL received the allegations made by a youth at the
facility. The allegations included additional information regarding
meals, clothing, and transportation at the facility. Those issues
were not investigated, as they are not required services from an
Independent Living Program (ILP).
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the ILP house on 3/27/22.
Youth A reported that staff intentionally do things to get youth
kicked out of the house. Youth A discussed an incident where
Youth C went out and left her child with a peer. Youth C was told
by staff that she cannot leave her child. Youth A was upset
because she felt staff could not tell a Youth C how to parent her
child. Youth A and others were angry, yelling at staff, and wrote on
the white board in the common area. Youth A stated she wanted
to make a report to Children’s Service so all of the staff would be
fired. Youth A reported that Supervisor gave her the number to
contact Children’s Services. When asked what staff had done that
specifically involved derogatory language, threats, intimidation or
racism, Youth A could not provide examples. Youth A complained
about staff not providing transportation, clothing, and food. Youth
A was advised of the expectations of Independent Living and
informed that ILP are not required to provide those items. Youth A
stated she did not like any of the food there and believed the “P” in
ILP meant “plus” as in, staff are supposed to provide everything
youth want and take youth wherever they want. This seemed to be
the source of Youth A’s anger, as she felt the agency was not
doing what she thought they should. Youth A reported she did not
have any examples of what was alleged but had heard information
from another youth that she believed was “kicked out” of the
program for complaining. Youth A felt she should make a report
since the youth is no longer there. An investigation (SIR
2022C0212020) was previously completed regarding this youth,
with no violations found. When asked again about any staff
participating in what was alleged, Youth A stated that she typically
sees Supervisor, Staff 1, and Staff 2. Youth A reported things she
did not like about those staff, but she did not provide any specifics
regarding the allegation. Youth A reported she refused to speak
with any of the staff to discuss her concerns.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the ILP house on 3/27/22.
Youth B reported she was aware of the allegation as she heard
rumors. Youth B indicated there was an incident recently where
2

youth were upset about Youth C getting in trouble for going out
and leaving her baby with another youth. Youth A, Youth C, and
Youth D were “riled up” at the house that night and threatening to
call Children’s Services on the agency. The youth reportedly felt
the agency did not have a right to tell Youth C how to parent her
child. Youth B stated she was not part of the incident and had not
witnessed any incidents of staff speaking inappropriately to youth,
making threats, or discriminating toward anyone. Youth B verified
that staff made the Children’s Services number available to youth.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the ILP house on 3/27/22.
Youth C was still upset with the agency about the incident that
happened a few nights prior. Youth C felt the agency did not have
the right to tell her how to parent her baby. Youth C was asked
about the allegation but she did not provide any information
specific to what was reported. Youth C stated that she believed
staff were supposed to provide youth with everything they need for
themselves and their babies. It was explained to Youth C what the
IL rule requirements are for the agency and what is expected of
the youth. Regarding the allegation, Youth C stated she believed
staff were bribing white youth to be on their side, which she felt
was racist. Youth C reported that one white youth was called to
the staff offices on the night of the incident, and the other youth
believed staff were trying to bribe that youth not to help the other
youth that were upset. Youth C did not have any specific
information about bribes from staff.
Youth D was interviewed face-to-face at the ILP house on 3/27/22.
Youth D was aware of the allegations and did not have any
specific information regarding them. Youth D reported frustrations
about staff not paying to get her phone fixed and other issues that
are not requirements for IL staff. Youth D stated that Supervisor is
rude and unreasonable. Citing that Supervisor has called law
enforcement when a youth did not return to the house. Youth D
felt that was unnecessary. Youth D felt the agency was “corrupt”
but did not have any examples other than hearsay about why
another youth left the program. Youth D stated that Supervisor
tries to tell the youth what to do. Youth D stated she believes
Supervisor does this in an attempt to upset youth and make them
leave the program. Youth D stated that Supervisor once
threatened to kick a peer out. Upon further questioning, it was
determined this was hearsay.
Youth E was interviewed face-to-face at the ILP house on 3/27/22.
Youth E reported that staff handled the incident with Youth C
inappropriately. Youth E also reported being upset that staff tell
3

youth how to care for their babies. Youth E stated that when she
voiced her concerns to Supervisor, Youth E was told she was
being disrespectful. Youth E stated that she was about to be
kicked out of the program for being disrespectful. Youth E stated
she has not observed staff to yell or swear at youth. Youth E
reported Supervisor lies about everything and youth do not like
her “tone of voice”. When asked for an example, Youth E reported
that Supervisor lied about small things that do not matter; but
could not provide an example. Youth E did not observe any
instances of swearing, threatening, or discriminating against
youth.
Supervisor was interviewed face-to-face at the ILP house on
3/27/22. Supervisor denied any use of derogatory language or
swearing at youth. Supervisor denied being part of or observing
any racial discrimination toward youth. Supervisor denied
threatening to kick youth out of placement. However, she reported
that at times youth have stated they did not like the program and
wanted to leave. Supervisor told youth they are not required to
stay there, unlike residential, and youth can contact their DHHS
worker to discuss other options. Supervisor denied participating in
or observing any intimidation of youth that wished to contact
Children’s Services. Supervisor reported that she and all staff
provide youth with information to call in a complaint if they wish.
Supervisor reported there are ongoing issues with rumors among
the youth. Whenever a youth leaves the program, the rumor
seems to spread that the youth was kicked out. As staff cannot tell
the youth the reason for peers leaving, they have difficulty
stopping the rumors. For example, Youth E will be leaving the
program at the request of her probation officer. However, word
has already spread that she was “kicked out” because of the
recent situation with Youth C.
Chief Administrator was interviewed face-to-face at the ILP house
on 3/27/22. Although Chief Administrator is not present in the
house every day, she noted that she has not observed any
intimidation, profanity, threats, or discrimination by staff, toward
youth. Chief Administrator reported no concerns about
Supervisor’s interactions with youth. Neither Supervisor, Staff 1
nor Staff 2 have any disciplinary action on file regarding any
behavior implied in the allegations.
Staff 1 was interviewed by phone on 4/5/23. Staff 1 reported
working in the ILP home on an almost daily basis. Staff 1 was
familiar with all youth of the home, and aware of the complaint.
Staff 1 denied ever observing or participating in swearing, yelling,
4

threatening, or racial discrimination. Staff 1 reported she had
previously provided the number for Children’s Services to youth
that wished to make a complaint. This is the standard practice for
staff. Staff 1 did not have any concerns regarding Supervisor.
Staff 1 had not observed Supervisor to act inappropriately with
youth. Staff 1 stated she believed it was common for complaints to
be about the person in charge, as it was easy for youth to blame
that person when youth did not get their way. Staff 1 noted that
Supervisor is on-site more frequently lately. Previously, it may
have been easier for youth to do what they wanted, when
Supervisor was not around. Now that she has more of a presence,
they may be frustrated by the consistency and expectations that
are set.
Staff 2 was interviewed by phone on 4/5/23. Staff 2 reported
working in the ILP home regularly. Staff 2 was familiar with all
youth of the home. Staff 2 denied ever hearing or participating in
yelling, swearing, threatening, or racial discrimination. Staff 2
reported providing contact information to youth that wished to
contact DCWL or Children’s Services. Staff 2 did not have any
concerns about the way Supervisor interacts with youth. Staff 2
indicated that youth seem to focus their frustration at Supervisor,
as she is the person in charge.
Documents
• A photograph was taken of the dry erase board located in a
common area of the house. On the night the complaint was
made, Youth A and two others wrote several statements
about staff on the board, which they labeled “hate chart”.
The board was covered in racial comments, derogatory
remarks, and threats toward staff. The less offensive
messages included, “finna lose yall jobs”, “need to leave
and get fired”, “erase it and I’m calling CPS”, “I promise to
get yall fired”, “I’m calling CPS on you (Supervisor, Staff 1
and Staff 2) so this whole place can get investigated and
shut down”, “This place getting shut down”, “CPS watching
yall, I’m telling everything”.
• The youth’s case files were reviewed in MiSACWIS on
3/24/22. No information relevant to the investigation was
found.
• The agency’s prior investigations were reviewed on
3/24/22. No prior violations of this rule were found.
Analysis Based on interviews completed with youth and staff, no violation
was found.
Technical Assistance
5

During interviews with youth in the ILP it was apparent the youth
misunderstood what the agency is required to provide.
Clarification was provided to some of the youth during interviews.
The agency was advised to provide greater clarity about program
services versus youth responsibilities to incoming youth,
specifically youth that have babies.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
I recommend no change in the license status.
